use.text: We can use our scale for good, and catalyze change across entire industries so that Starbucks and everyone we touch can endure and thrive
It’s because people see this going on and now they will be more likely to take action themselves

Just as Starbucks does not accept the status quo in our business, and proactively embraces innovative products and ideas, we also look for and champion freshinventive ways to use our existing assets and resources beyond business
We know that our supply chain is vast, and we have an opportunity to use its scale to make positive changes industry-wide
In 2012, 98% of our contracts included an economic transparency clause
Our Cocoa Practices program seeks to verify the supply chain for the cocoa beans used in our beverages, with inspections performed by independent verifiers overseen by SCS Global Services
Our goal is to invest in Improve farmers Inmarkets, Trade Access Fund set up by Incofin Investment e focused ng  our farmer    providing rmers nt      $15

By building more energy-efficient stores and facilities, conserving the energy and water we use and purchasing renewable energy credits, we are pushing ourselves to reduce the environmental footprint of our business operations
stores by 2015 Greener Stores We know that more than 80% of our direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions come from the energy used to power our stores, offices and roasting plants
We are intently focused on improving the environmental performance of our facilities and more than 18,000 stores with green store design and energy and24

In collecting data from our stores around the world and analyzing customer behavior, we determined that a better measurement of this goal is to calculate the percentage of times a personal cup/tumbler is used over our total beverage sales, which is a more precise measure of the total beverages we sell
We challenge ourselves, our partners in our support centers and our stores, to use reusable cups and remain committed to exploring new ways to reduce our cup waste
In the first 12 months of the Community Store program, this effort generated $245,000 for holistic community- revitalization programs focused on education, safety, housing, health and employment

Starbucks Global Responsibility Report – Goals and Progress 2012 15    About the 2012 Starbucks Responsibility Report Scope The report for fiscal 2012 focuses on our performance against the goals we set in 2008 in three areas: ethical sourcing, environmental stewardship and community involvement
Boundaries Our Global Responsibility Report for fiscal year 2012 focuses on the work we are doing in ethical sourcing, community involvement and environmental stewardship
While our commitments are global, our report content is focused largely on Starbucks U
Starbucks has used the Credit360 system for key performance indicators data entry, approval and audit

supply chain.text: We know that our supply chain is vast, and we have an opportunity to use its scale to make positive changes industry-wide

Tea In a similar way we approach responsible coffee sourcing, we are committed to a long-term strategy of ethical tea sourcing, which includes helping support farmers and their communities throughout our tea supply chain
Our Cocoa Practices program seeks to verify the supply chain for the cocoa beans used in our beverages, with inspections performed by independent verifiers overseen by SCS Global Services
Starbucks is a member of the Global Social Compliance Program, a business-driven effort to promote GOAL the continuous improvement of environmental and working conditions of global supply chains
We are also working in critical areas of our supply chain to mitigate our impacts and adapt to a changing climate
But it’s about more than just our operations and supply chain
To better understand the risk to farming communities and our supply chain, we work with Conservation International (CI) and farmers in three unique coffee-producing communities
and Canada company- owned and operated retail stores and global supply chain operations

tea supply chain.text: Tea In a similar way we approach responsible coffee sourcing, we are committed to a long-term strategy of ethical tea sourcing, which includes helping support farmers and their communities throughout our tea supply chain

global supply chain.text: Starbucks is a member of the Global Social Compliance Program, a business-driven effort to promote GOAL the continuous improvement of environmental and working conditions of global supply chains
and Canada company- owned and operated retail stores and global supply chain operations

support health.text: In tea-growing regions of India and botanical-farming communities in Guatemala, Starbucks has helped support health and economic development programs through Tazo’s Community Health and Advancement Initiative (CHAI) project, a joint partnership with Mercy Corps

health.text: This is to ensure the long-term sustainability of our business and the health of the communities we touch
In the first 12 months of the Community Store program, this effort generated $245,000 for holistic community- revitalization programs focused on education, safety, housing, health and employment

In Indonesia’s Aceh province, Starbucks has teamed with Save the Children to improve children’s health and education in coffee-growing communities through BLEND (Better Living, Education, Nutrition, and Development)
Participating communities have doubled their vaccination rates, drastically improved health worker capacity, and quadrupled the number of community health posts

In tea-growing regions of India and botanical-farming communities in Guatemala, Starbucks has helped support health and economic development programs through Tazo’s Community Health and Advancement Initiative (CHAI) project, a joint partnership with Mercy Corps

In 2011 Starbucks launched a three-year project with a $1 million contribution to Save the Children to improve education, health and nutrition for coffee-farming families in Guatemala’s Huehuetenango region

community health.text: Participating communities have doubled their vaccination rates, drastically improved health worker capacity, and quadrupled the number of community health posts

quality.text: We strive to cultivate lasting relationships with the people who grow our products and create our manufactured goods as we work together to produce high-quality, ethically sourced products
Coffee GOAL We are committed to buying and serving high-quality coffee that is responsibly grown and ethically traded
) Practices, our comprehensive coffee-buying program that ensures coffee quality while promoting social, economic and environmental standards

Another important component of our approach is a green coffee pricing model that aims to pay the prices premium quality commands, while fostering price stability and mutually beneficial relationships with suppliers
Starbucks sourced 545 million pounds of premium quality green (unroasted) coffee from 29 countries in 2012, and paid an average price of $2

Cocoa Our approach to buying cocoa is also based on a commitment to ensuring a long-term supply of high-quality, ethically sourced cocoa while contributing positively to the environment and to cocoa-farming communities
coffee purchases with quality and size of their harvests

climate change.text: We are seeing the impacts of climate change on our planet and are working to minimize our own environmental footprint
3 million placed in the Fair and/or to regional climate changes,         Foundation and Fairtrade International
Beyond the proactive efforts within our control, the realities of climate change are a growing challenge, and we felt the impact during 2012 – the hottest year on record
We also know that the magnitude and complexity of addressing climate change requires us to think beyond the actions of our own company

air.text: We’ve been building a company with a conscience for more than four decades, intent on the fair and humane treatment of our people as well as the communities where we do business, and the global environment we all share
In 2012, we appointed renowned community advocate and entrepreneurial leader Blair Taylor to serve in our newly created role of chief community officer
A true visionary, Blair leads our community, partner resources, government relations, diversity and global responsibility teams

Warm regards,     Howard Schultz chairman, president and chief executive officer     Starbucks Global Responsibility Report – Goals and Progress 2012 2   Ethical Sourcing     We have taken a holistic approach to ethically sourcing our products – from the coffee we serve our customers to the green aprons worn by our baristas

waste reduction.text: Reducing Waste with Reusable Cups Reusable cups are an important component of our overall waste reduction strategy

waste.text: We are also working to shrink our environmental footprint and meet the expectations of our customers by reducing the waste associated with our cups, increasing recycling and incorporating green design into our stores
For example, in the United Kingdom store waste is separated into three streams in the back of our stores, and then separated later at the waste facility
Our UK stores are currently diverting approximately 50% of their waste from landfills with this method, and we are testing ways to increase capabilities in markets newer to recycling

front-of-store recycling Back-of-store recycling is also a priority, as most of our in-store waste is generated company-owned the 3,178 stores in the United States and Canada where Starbucks is responsible storescardboard recycled limited by operational impasses, such as a lack of store space for recycling carts or the unavailability 18% recycling services

Reducing Waste with Reusable Cups Reusable cups are an important component of our overall waste reduction strategy
We’ll continue to find innovative ways to engage customers to work with us to reduce waste, including launching a $1 reusable cup in the U
We challenge ourselves, our partners in our support centers and our stores, to use reusable cups and remain committed to exploring new ways to reduce our cup waste

reduce water.text: GOAL In 2008 we set a goal to reduce water consumption by 25% in company-owned stores by 2015

training.text: We are investing in the development of the Aceh Tengah Coffee Climate Change Adaption plan, building the first of six nurseries in 2012, organizing climate mitigation and adaption trainings for farmers, and establishing plans to plant 300,000 trees by 2013
Community Stores serve as the hub of our community service and training programs that promote leadership and job and life-skill development

support health.text: In tea-growing regions of India and botanical-farming communities in Guatemala, Starbucks has helped support health and economic development programs through Tazo’s Community Health and Advancement Initiative (CHAI) project, a joint partnership with Mercy Corps

health.text: This is to ensure the long-term sustainability of our business and the health of the communities we touch
In the first 12 months of the Community Store program, this effort generated $245,000 for holistic community- revitalization programs focused on education, safety, housing, health and employment

In Indonesia’s Aceh province, Starbucks has teamed with Save the Children to improve children’s health and education in coffee-growing communities through BLEND (Better Living, Education, Nutrition, and Development)
Participating communities have doubled their vaccination rates, drastically improved health worker capacity, and quadrupled the number of community health posts

In tea-growing regions of India and botanical-farming communities in Guatemala, Starbucks has helped support health and economic development programs through Tazo’s Community Health and Advancement Initiative (CHAI) project, a joint partnership with Mercy Corps

In 2011 Starbucks launched a three-year project with a $1 million contribution to Save the Children to improve education, health and nutrition for coffee-farming families in Guatemala’s Huehuetenango region

collecting data.text: In collecting data from our stores around the world and analyzing customer behavior, we determined that a better measurement of this goal is to calculate the percentage of times a personal cup/tumbler is used over our total beverage sales, which is a more precise measure of the total beverages we sell

waste reduction.text: Reducing Waste with Reusable Cups Reusable cups are an important component of our overall waste reduction strategy

waste.text: We are also working to shrink our environmental footprint and meet the expectations of our customers by reducing the waste associated with our cups, increasing recycling and incorporating green design into our stores
For example, in the United Kingdom store waste is separated into three streams in the back of our stores, and then separated later at the waste facility
Our UK stores are currently diverting approximately 50% of their waste from landfills with this method, and we are testing ways to increase capabilities in markets newer to recycling

front-of-store recycling Back-of-store recycling is also a priority, as most of our in-store waste is generated company-owned the 3,178 stores in the United States and Canada where Starbucks is responsible storescardboard recycled limited by operational impasses, such as a lack of store space for recycling carts or the unavailability 18% recycling services

Reducing Waste with Reusable Cups Reusable cups are an important component of our overall waste reduction strategy
We’ll continue to find innovative ways to engage customers to work with us to reduce waste, including launching a $1 reusable cup in the U
We challenge ourselves, our partners in our support centers and our stores, to use reusable cups and remain committed to exploring new ways to reduce our cup waste

quality.text: We strive to cultivate lasting relationships with the people who grow our products and create our manufactured goods as we work together to produce high-quality, ethically sourced products
Coffee GOAL We are committed to buying and serving high-quality coffee that is responsibly grown and ethically traded
) Practices, our comprehensive coffee-buying program that ensures coffee quality while promoting social, economic and environmental standards

Another important component of our approach is a green coffee pricing model that aims to pay the prices premium quality commands, while fostering price stability and mutually beneficial relationships with suppliers
Starbucks sourced 545 million pounds of premium quality green (unroasted) coffee from 29 countries in 2012, and paid an average price of $2

Cocoa Our approach to buying cocoa is also based on a commitment to ensuring a long-term supply of high-quality, ethically sourced cocoa while contributing positively to the environment and to cocoa-farming communities

value.text: For Starbucks, these metrics are important indications of how we are growing our brand and returning value to our shareholders
But equally important to the value we create are the values we live by

Capturing the carbon value of this investment in tree plantings has helped farmers receive additional income in the form of payments for carbon credits – creating the equivalent of 22 new jobs and representing an average of nearly 27% of a participating farmer’s income
At Starbucks we strive to create a culture that values and respects diversity and inclusion
”   To strengthen these efforts, we also collaborate with diverse professional organizations, nonprofit organizations, businesses, civic leaders and individuals who share our values
